awd_abstract_narration:
Communications metadata is necessary for the delivery of services. But such metadata leaks information about user intent and behavior. Through timing, for example, one can determine whether a Twitter account is a bot, while through packet length, what language is being spoken in an encrypted Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP) call. Thus, protecting a user's privacy and security is complicated. By examining multiple different sets of metadata usage, this EAGER seeks to develop a categorization of the types of information that metadata reveals.  Applications of the work should lead to the development of better technical and policy protections of user privacy and security. 

The main contribution of this proposed research is a categorization of the types of uses to which metadata is applied. There are many uses in metadata usage (how is the data collected, is it aggregated with other data, etc.); this categorization will focus on developing clean types of information revealed through metadata capture and use.  Such a categorization of metadata usage will have several important applications. Delineating different types of knowledge gained through the use of metadata (e.g., information about the device, information about the user), will simplify providing better technical protections for user privacy and security against such attacks. Furthermore, by categorizing the different ways metadata is used, it will be possible to more easily understand which usages are privacy invasive and which are not, and thus to develop more privacy-protective policies surrounding metadata usage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Smartphones have become an essential device for navigating modern life, and they bring huge benefits. They enable us to conduct a work call while at a doctor's office with a sick child, check in for a flight, show proof of a Covid vaccine, enable us to respond to email between meetings, and share photos of our children and grandchildren. But as we traverse train stations, office buildings, city streets, and country roads, these remarkably versatile devices leak data about our daily activities to ISPs, to random WiFi networks, to apps, and to websites. Much of this information is aggregated, creating fine-tuned portraits that without our knowledge?and often without our ability to control the situation?are shared with advertisers and others. This research studied the privacy threats stemming from private-sector use of smartphone communications metadata and software and device telemetry (software telemetry reports how software on the device is performing and reports problems; device telemetry includes reports from the accelerometer, battery sensor, gyroscope, magnetometer and other sensors on the phone).

When a user enters terms into a search or mapping application, she knows she is providing personal information. When a user communicates via an encrypted Voice over IP (VoIP) call, she has no idea that the communications metadata?information provided to third parties without her control?leaks what language she is speaking and even sometimes what she is saying. And when a user shuts off GPS collection so as to keep her destination private from applications, she doesn't know that other information?accelerometer, gyroscope, and magnetometer data, may provide information to apps about her location?including what office or room she is within a building. So while the GPS data she carefully shut off simply could have reported that the user had arrived at a set of medical offices, the data from on-device sensors could reveal her path within the building. It could reveal whether the user had gone to the oncologist's office or the psychologist's.

In a previous era, the regulated telephone monopoly, AT&T collected and measured trunk traffic essentially from its beginning to determine how its services were working. It also recorded customer use of the telephone system for billing purposes. With the arrival of IP-based communications and smart phones, search collection and usage went into overdrive. The nature of IP based routing and delivery means that there is much richer data in Internet communications that had been in the Public Switched Telephone Network. When the world moved to cloud services, there was interest in collecting "telemetry" information: data about how the software was working.

As cellphones became smartphones, the devices acquired sensors, including accelerometers, gyroscopes, magnetometers, power sensors, proximity sensors, ambient noise sensors, and power sensors. Sensors are useful for ensuring smartphones functioned properly and provided services, such as mapping applications. But the data from sensors also proved useful off device as well. U.S. and foreign industry has been patenting the use of communications metadata and sensor information for use in what most would view as intruding upon increasingly private issues. While some information derived from communications metadata and software and device telemetry can have high public benefit, e.g., location of mobile phones can help predict spread of disease (and thus get resources in places quickly) or movement of people on public transportation can provide useful information for urban planners, other types of information can be used in discriminatory and other harmful ways.

This research categorized the type of information that can be discerned from communications metadata and software and device telemetry. It also examined the harms to people that can result from the use of such information and analyzed the ability of users to employ current policy protections, namely Notice and Consent, to handle the collection and use of such data. Finally, the research proposed solutions for protecting user privacy in the context of data for which users are unable to prevent and/or unaware of collection and thus effectively unable to control use.
